The last two 3:30pm sittings have been challenging. Restless body and proliferating mind. I guess it's my time of day for anxiety. How do I reconcile this practice of relinquishment with the reality that I am a wife, mother and householder? With love.

If the body is a sack of grains, my legs after 7 / 7:30pm are electric jumping beans. This has occurred on retreat for 30 years. At first, I assumed it was the usual resistances / saṅkhāras. For a decade, I’ve known it’s a neurological syndrome that many have (R.L.S.) and although it affects other parts of life, e.g., sleep, it’s never so intense as on retreat in the evening. As I calm and cleanse, it actually gets worse, even on longer retreats. If I don’t focus on exhaling calm and mettā, I would drive my neighbors crazy, twitching and squirming like a bored 4 year-old. But I’m not bored and I want to hear the teachings. The level of controlling the legs necessarily, even with calming, creates sometimes a kind of negative pīti—thunderbolts in the body with no delight or rapture! I intuit an ancient root to it but, what to do? Alternative and western guidance have not helped much. From your vast experience of squirming mediators, any advice? Any research on sitting and milder neurological phenomena like this? Right now, besides leaving the hall / tortured endurance / drugs / cutting off my legs, suggestions for a middle way?!

This is to help prevent my mind from becoming too proud, or thinking I have attained some state when not.

I see a lot of heart and compassion in the Dhamma now and I am learning more about women in Buddhism. It would be great to hear more stories about them in Dhamma talks and perhaps one day even have a guest nun visit and give a talk. Thank you.

excerpts.text: It's understandable that we crave happiness through the senses. Attaching to a certain type of happiness through the senses is not helpful for cultivation. But there's also the emphasis on joy in the Buddha's teachings. So there should be a balance, and where to find that?

annotations.text: All the elements of the path are a source of happiness and well-being.
What about the joy that comes from enjoying sensual things like music, painting, scents, and water?

SRD2010.title: Recollections of Ajahn Chah
SRD2010.subtitle: His Life and Teachings
SRD2010.description: During this daylong retreat, Ajahn Pasanno shares teachings and memories of his beloved teacher, Ajahn Chah. By the time of his passing in 1992, Ajahn Chah had become one of the most highly revered Buddhist meditation masters in Thailand. The readings come from a draft version of Ajahn Jayasaro's biography of Ajahn Chah that was published as [Stillness Flowing](Stillness Flowing) in 2018.

SRD2011.title: Tudong Stories at Spirit Rock
SRD2011.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers stories of tudong (wandering pilgrimage) at daylong event at Spirit Rock Meditation Center

UD2012-4.title: The Gradual Training
UD2012-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno and Ajahn Yatiko describe the Buddha's progressive teaching, which begins by encouraging generosity and virtue and goes on to describe the joys of heaven, the drawbacks in sensuality, the benefits of renunciation, and the Four Noble Truths.

UD2013-1.title: Right Livelihood
UD2013-1.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads from P. A. Payutto’s _Buddhist Economics_ and _A Constitution for Living_ and answers questions related to the topic of right livelihood.

SRD2013.title: The Whole of the Path: The Fruits of Spiritual Friendship

TG2013.title: Abhayagiri Monastic Retreat 2013
TG2013.subtitle: Brightening the Mind
TG2013.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. However, after the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly.

WR2014.title: Abhayagiri 2014 Winter Retreat
WR2014.subtitle: Our Roots in the Thai Forest Tradition
WR2014.description: The Abhayagiri Community took turns reading from translations of the Thai Forest masters. Ajahn Pasanno answers the many questions that followed the readings.

UD2014-2.title: Thai Forest Tradition
UD2014-2.description: Ajahn Pasanno and Ajahn Karuṇadhammo present the Thai

UD2014-3.title: Mindfulness of Breathing
UD2014-3.description: Ajahn Pasanno describes mindfulness of breathing as a method to firmly establish the mind and develop insight.

DRBU2014.title: Questions and Answers with Dharma Realm Buddhist University
DRBU2014.description: A small group from the Dharma Realm Buddhist University (DRBU) located at the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas (CTTB) spent the morning at Abhayagiri. The group included two bhikkshunis as well as a number of resident volunteers at the CTTB. The students are in DRBU’s Masters of Arts in Buddhist Classics program. This semester the students have been reading various spiritual biographies including the biographies of the Thai Forest masters Ajahn Mun, Ajahn Tate and Ajahn Lee Dhammadharo. The audio is from their question and answer session with Ajahn Pasanno.

TG2014.title: 2014 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2014.subtitle: “Just Right” Practice
TG2014.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. However, after the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly.

SRD2015.title: Desire or Aspiration
SRD2015.subtitle: Can a Buddhist Want Anything?
SRD2015.description: Ajahn Pasanno differentiates between skillful and unskillful desire, distinguishing between two Pāli words that are translated as desire: taṇhā, which is a cause of suffering, and chanda, which is one of the Four Bases of Success.

UD2015-3.title: Buddhist Identity in the Modern World
UD2015-3.description: After introducing the topic of Buddhist identity in the modern world, Ajahn Pasanno leads a discussion around this theme.

UD2015-4.title: Jhāna: A Practical Approach
UD2015-4.description: Ajahn Pasanno explains jhāna as a fundamental clarity and stillness that the mind can experience.

TG2015.title: 2015 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat
TG2015.subtitle: Mindfulness of Feeling
TG2015.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. However, after the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly.

UD2016-2.title: Suttas You've Never Heard Of
UD2016-2.description: Ajahn Pasanno reads and discusses a series of suttas regarding the human condition.

Teen2017.title: Teen Weekend 2017
Teen2017.description: This question and answer session was offered as part of the Teen Weekend on September 2, 2017 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

WR2018-2.title: The Teaching and the Training
WR2018-2.subtitle: Eleven interviews with Ajahn Pasanno
WR2018-2.description: Towards the end of Winter Retreat 2018, Tan Suhajjo and the Abhayagiri Community ask Ajahn Pasanno questions related to monastic life.

Path2019.title: The Path of Practice
Path2019.description: A weekend retreat lead by Ajahn Pasanno at the Victoria Insight Meditation Society in June 2019.

Stanford2020.title: Stanford Community Dhamma Discussion
Stanford2020.subtitle: Reflections on the Path
Stanford2020.description: Ajahn Pasanno offers a live stream Dhamma talk and Q&A for the Buddhist Community at Stanford (BCAS).

UD2020.title: Living in a Changing Society
UD2020.subtitle: Dealing with Fear, Stress, and Worry and Cultivating Kindness, Patient Endurance, and Harmony

UD2021-1.title: Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta
UD2021-1.description: Under the umbrella theme of “Devotion & Ritual,” the first Upāsika Day of 2021 was on the topic of Honoring the Buddha: The Mahāparinibbāna Sutta, DN 16.

Manijeh2021.title: Tea Time Q&A with Ajahn Pasanno
Manijeh2021.description: Manijeh Motaghy facilitates a Question and Answer session on Zoom with Venerable Ajahn Pasanno regarding how to use the Buddha’s teachings to relieve the stress of life.

Kathina2021.title: Abhayagiri Kaṭhina 2021
Kathina2021.description: Abhayagiri Monastery spread the 2021 Kaṭhina festival over a period of seven days to accommodate the necessities of the pandemic. Question and answers were recorded on days two and four.

Thanksgiving Retreats.description: The Abhayagiri Monastic Thanksgiving retreat was traditionally an annual ten-day residential retreat held at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa, California during the week of Thanksgiving. However, after the Angela Center closed due to fire damage in 2017 and the COVID pandemic began in 2020, the location, date, duration, and format of this retreat have varied significantly.

Abhayagiri Winter Retreats.description: During the months of January, February, and March, the resident community of Abhayagiri Monastery ceases all non-essential work to practice meditation. There are usually Dhamma readings nearly every day, some of which end with questions and answers regarding the teachings.

annotations.text: Debbie transcribed Ajahn Pasanno's 2008 Metta Retreat, published it as [Abundant, Exalted, Immeasurable](https://www.abhayagiri.org/books/584-abundant-exalted-immeasurable), and dedicated the merit to her mother.
Hospice workers took the body of my father-in-law away too quickly.
When my husband died, we kept and washed the body.
_A New Course in Reading Pāli_ by James W. Gair and W. S. Karunatillake ([pdf](https://buddhistuniversity.net/content/monographs/new-course-in-reading-pali_gair-karunatillake))
Bhikkhu Bodhi's _Reading the Buddha's Discourses in Pāli_ was published in 2020.
